channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description:
Now one of the problems of the #neuroscience community is that we're all split among multiple platforms. Really too bad.
And I really mean it. Aside from graduate school, from 2019 to 2022 was probably the time that I learned the most about the brain because of the vast amount of material shared on social media. It was great fun for some time. üòî

item.title: Erik Uden ü¶£
item.description: A man in Saudi Arabia has been sentenced to death for his tweets, and surprise: Elon Musk is NOT funding his legal bill as promised because there's a good chance that the necessary data to identify this man came from the second largest shareholder of Twitter: the Saudi prince Alwaleed bin Talal. Musk has been awfully silent about this as you can't really make your ‚Äúfreedom of speech!!‚Äù argument when you assist with killing a retired teacher for the regime critic posts they made on your platform, only possible because that regime owns a huge chunk of ‚Äúyour‚Äù platform.

item.title: Theresa Desrochers
item.description: At some point on social media I saw a post about developing a publishing agreement with trainees who were leaving the lab. I thought it was a great idea, but now can't find where I saw it. Does anyone have a resource like that they would be willing to share or have something they could point me to?#academia #publishing

item.title: David Pfau
item.description: Thrilled to share what I‚Äôve been working on for the last two years - a new way to solve one of the most fundamental problems in quantum physics, computing excited states! https://arxiv.org/abs/2308.16848

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: The things you find in closets at MIT. An old device that used electricity to make clinical lesions (controlled damage) in the human brain to treat disorders. There is a Shudder channel movie script in there somewhere.

item.title: Cat Hicks
item.description: I wrote about the idea of craft -- a concept I've been hearing a lot lately in conversations about software work and often find myself wrangling with. But it also turned out to be about my grandpa. In a year of many losses, I have been thinking a lot about those I love and try to take with me in everything I do. https://www.drcathicks.com/post/on-craft

item.title: It's The Weekend
Nicole Rust
item.description:
@elduvelle @PessoaBrain @kordinglab
To be clear, I really appreciate Mastodon and my experience here. What I particularly love about it is interacting with individuals, most often related to how the brain works (and breaks) with individuals of all types (scientists and non-scientists alike). It's the interaction here that is really special. It's authentic and honest and more often than not, focused on learning from one another. To channel what I know to be the complaints of some others:1) Some individuals aren't just interested in social media for interaction. They have a message to spread and Mastodon is simply not the best platform for "reach". If you want to convince as many people as you can about Covid/Global Warming/etc, Mastodon is not a bad way but it's also not the best way. And it won't ever be the best. There's no algorithm to spread the word, etc. Insofar as we brain researchers want to also be public facing scientific communicators, this is relevant. Similarly, if you want to reach a community beyond, say, neuroscience (URMs, PhD students at large, etc), this is relevant.2) A lot of individuals find the Mastodon community alienating, for a few reasons. For some, when they are engaged in social media, many want to be lighthearted and have fun. That's not the vibe here; rather, the vibe is pretty serious. There are a lot of social norms and a lot of pile on for violating them. If you are naturally on board with those norms, it's no big deal (and I feel this is generally the case for me - it's easy). But if you like to shit post, you may run into some issues. Many people don't want to feel they are walking on eggshells to engage. Similarly, this platform also has a history of not treating certain communities very well, which once again, is alienating.

item.title: MCDuncanLab
item.description: @askennard DpnI digest your PCR to remove template.PPTase vector and if possible digest with a third enzyme to prevent religation of excised MCS.

item.title: Dan Gillmor
item.description: A person I otherwise deeply respect has remained (very) active on the deadbird site, and is even paying for it, because (the person says) it fulfills a professional need that can't be met elsewhere. My friend calls it "a deal with the devil." On that, we agree.I have my share of hypocrisies, and try to manage them carefully. Sticking with a site run by an enemy of journalism and democracy was just too much to stomach.Journalists should leave. Period.

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: @FroehlichMarcel @NicoleCRust @elduvelle @PessoaBrain I guess I see your arguments against recommenders. But I find that feeds I get that are ordered for my preferences by an algorithm are much better than those that come from people I follow. Simply because I am weird. But it is a huge effect for me. Mastodon is good serious stuff. That I mostly don't care about.Its not even close. If I look at my home here, 90% of posts are just element number 20 of some discussion of a point that is not close to my heart. The experience is just booooring.

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: Gait based biomarkers are going to happen. Why am I positive? A good doctor can use them already. What a trained human eye can do an algorithm can learn as well. Progress in that direction is slow but steady. E.g. https://arxiv.org/pdf/2307.16321.pdf

item.title: Albert Cardona
item.description:
James W. Truman featured in the New Yorker. A warm, lovely piece on his career studying insect metamorphosis, from moths to flies and mosquitoes, and the role and impact of hormones on insect development and behaviour‚Äîmotivated by his latest work mapping the fate of neurons from larva to adult through pupal stages, and addressing an old question: do associative memories persist through metamorphosis?https://www.newyorker.com/science/elements/what-insects-go-through-is-even-weirder-than-we-thoughtThe paper:
‚ÄúMetamorphosis of memory circuits in Drosophila reveals a strategy for evolving a larval brain‚Äù Truman et al. 2023 https://elifesciences.org/articles/80594#neuroscience #entomology #metamorphosis #insects #ecdyzone #Drosophila #moths #mosquitoes #NewYorker

item.title: franco_vazza
item.description: Considering that the volume in a 1000 Mpc distance is dominated by voids, the consensus is that the suppression of the secondary Inverse Compton Cascade reported by many observations (and not limited to Fermi_LAT observations, but also MAGIC, VERITAS, HESS‚Ä¶) is a proof for the existence of a tiny magnetisation of the emptiest regions in the Universe!

item.title: Virgile Andreani
item.description:
"Truthfully, I gave up the piano for two solid months. And I had crying fits at night. I would go to bed at night and it haunted me, it actually haunted me that someone could play the piano so well."
‚Äî virtuoso pianist Oscar Peterson on the first time he heard Art TatumWhen impostor syndrome gets me, I always try to remember that even Oscar Peterson came close to quitting because he felt not good enough.The full interview of Peterson: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BFNsywQOW1I#ImpostorSyndrome #Academia
